ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Yes! They did a great job at presenting ethical issues that researchers may face.
It's a useful course and it's required.
You learn alot about the behind the curtain of how science works and all the guidlines we have to think about as we are doing good science.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I really appreciated this class. I went in with a bad attitude because I thought it was just some requirement from the NIH. But I ended up looking forward to the class. It was stress free compared to all of my courses with heavy work loads, and the lectures were always pertinent to us. I wanted to write a special note to the lecturer that covered human testing. I believe he had a law degree. Regardless, his lecture was able to cover the concerns of both scientists and activists. There was little bias in his talk, and the historical cases that he described were astounding.
It gives me the ethical knowledge in conducting the research, which is very necessary to learn.
